articles.headline: Murder Charge in a Shooting on Doorstep
articles.snippet: The prosecutor rejected a claim of self-defense in the shooting death of a young black Detroit woman by a white suburban homeowner.
articles.abstract: The prosecutor rejected a claim of self-defense in the shooting death of a young black Detroit woman by a white suburban homeowner.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — After a two-week investigation, the prosecutor here charged a white suburban homeowner on Friday with second-degree murder in the killing of an unarmed young black woman. The prosecutor rejected the man’s assertion that he had been acting in self-defense when he opened his front door and fired a shotgun at the woman through a locked screen door, striking her in the face.

articles.headline: Streaming and Cable Deal for ‘The Simpsons’
articles.snippet: The series, which has more than 500 episodes, has been widely syndicated but not on cable TV. The price was expected to approach $1 billion.
articles.abstract: The series, which has more than 500 episodes, has been widely syndicated but not on cable TV. The price was expected to approach $1 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: In one of television’s biggest syndication deals, “The Simpsons,” the longest-running scripted show in TV history, will finally be moving to cable television — and, not too surprisingly, it is staying in the family.

articles.headline: Jury Finds Pipe Maker Defrauded Governments
articles.snippet: Three years after a whistle-blower’s original complaint, a federal jury in California has found JM Eagle to be responsible for selling defective PVC pipes to municipalities across the country.
articles.abstract: Three years after a whistle-blower’s original complaint, a federal jury in California has found JM Eagle to be responsible for selling defective PVC pipes to municipalities across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal jury in California found on Thursday that the nation’s largest maker of plastic pipe defrauded states and municipalities over a decade by knowingly selling them defective pipe for use in their drinking water, firefighting, irrigation and other essential public systems.

articles.headline: Facebook Reasserts Posts Can Be Used to Advertise
articles.snippet: The company says it made more clear that postings and other personal data can be used in advertising on the site and reiterated that includes information from teenage users.
articles.abstract: The company says it made more clear that postings and other personal data can be used in advertising on the site and reiterated that includes information from teenage users.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — If you post something on Facebook, let there be no doubt that it can end up as an ad shown to your friends and acquaintances.

articles.headline: Baffling About-Face in American-US Airways Merger
articles.snippet: The settlement that ended the Justice Department’s lawsuit against the airlines left many antitrust experts with questions.
articles.abstract: The settlement that ended the Justice Department’s lawsuit against the airlines left many antitrust experts with questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Did the Justice Department cave?

articles.headline: Death After the Typhoon: ‘It Was Preventable’
articles.snippet: During five days in a Philippine hospital, a 27-year-old farmer and family breadwinner received virtually no care and died, in essence, of a broken leg.
articles.abstract: During five days in a Philippine hospital, a 27-year-old farmer and family breadwinner received virtually no care and died, in essence, of a broken leg.
articles.lead_paragraph: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Richard Pulga lay on a hard steel gurney for five days with only a saline drip after being seriously injured in the typhoon that devastated his country.

articles.headline: The Payoff in Waiting to Collect Social Security
articles.snippet: The longer a person of retirement age puts off collecting Social Security, the more money he or she will collect annually — much like buying an annuity.
articles.abstract: The longer a person of retirement age puts off collecting Social Security, the more money he or she will collect annually — much like buying an annuity.
articles.lead_paragraph: If an insurance salesman offered a product with a guaranteed income of nearly 7 percent for life, it would be foolish not to question whether it was too good to be true.

articles.headline: Young and Educated in Europe, but Desperate for Jobs
articles.snippet: High unemployment in countries like Spain, Portugal and Greece is hitting young people hardest as they take jobs below their skill level and seek work abroad.
articles.abstract: High unemployment in countries like Spain, Portugal and Greece is hitting young people hardest as they take jobs below their skill level and seek work abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID — Alba Méndez, a 24-year-old with a master’s degree in sociology, sprang out of bed nervously one recent morning, carefully put on makeup and styled her hair. Her thin hands trembled as she clutched her résumé on her way out of the tiny room where a friend allows her to stay rent free.

articles.headline: In a Bean, a Boon to Biotech
articles.snippet: A policy proposed by the Food and Drug Administration could make marketing genetically modified soybeans easier.
articles.abstract: A policy proposed by the Food and Drug Administration could make marketing genetically modified soybeans easier.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new federal push to purge artery-clogging trans fats from foods could be just what the doctor ordered — not only for public health but for the unpopular biotechnology industry, specifically, two developers of genetically modified crops.

articles.headline: Emotional Support, With Fur, Draws Complaints on Planes
articles.snippet: A growing number of fliers are accompanied by pets legally certified as emotional support animals, sometimes raising eyebrows, and doubts.
articles.abstract: A growing number of fliers are accompanied by pets legally certified as emotional support animals, sometimes raising eyebrows, and doubts.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Gigi Griffis, a writer who travels around the world as she works, and Luna, her sprightly 4-year-old Schnauzer-Yorkie mix, are nearly inseparable. They have dined in Mexican cafes near Puerto Vallarta, navigated the Paris Metro and hiked the alpine foothills of the Matterhorn.

articles.headline: Who Has Your Back? Hard to Tell
articles.snippet: Whether or not trustees have a duty to protect investors in mortgage cases is at the center of a multibillion dollar settlement struck by Bank of America for loans made by Countrywide Financial.
articles.abstract: Whether or not trustees have a duty to protect investors in mortgage cases is at the center of a multibillion dollar settlement struck by Bank of America for loans made by Countrywide Financial.
articles.lead_paragraph: What is the duty of a trustee to protect investors?

articles.headline: Reaching for Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: Georgia Tech longed to build a start-up culture, but it says a professor took it too far. Three years later, he is battling the university in court.
articles.abstract: Georgia Tech longed to build a start-up culture, but it says a professor took it too far. Three years later, he is battling the university in court.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joy Laskar was not what you’d typically think of as a threat to public safety.

articles.headline: Caught in a Revolving Door of Unemployment
articles.snippet: Some economists fear that the long-term unemployment crisis affecting millions of Americans might be a permanent change, with far-reaching and damaging consequences.
articles.abstract: Some economists fear that the long-term unemployment crisis affecting millions of Americans might be a permanent change, with far-reaching and damaging consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a cold October morning, just after the federal government shutdown came to an end, Jenner Barrington-Ward headed into court in Boston to declare bankruptcy.

articles.headline: A Russian GPS Using U.S. Soil Stirs Spy Fears
articles.snippet: American spy agencies fear that allowing monitor stations in the United States for Russia’s version of GPS could compromise American intelligence.
articles.abstract: American spy agencies fear that allowing monitor stations in the United States for Russia’s version of GPS could compromise American intelligence.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the view of America’s spy services, the next potential threat from Russia may not come from a nefarious cyberweapon or secrets gleaned from the files of Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor now in Moscow.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Growing Clamor About Inequities of Climate Crisis
articles.snippet: The devastation in the Philippines has revived the debate over how to address the disproportionate effects of climate change on poorer countries, an issue that has gained momentum but faces daunting challenges.
articles.abstract: The devastation in the Philippines has revived the debate over how to address the disproportionate effects of climate change on poorer countries, an issue that has gained momentum but faces daunting challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Following a devastating typhoon that killed thousands in the Philippines, a routine international climate change conference here turned into an emotional forum, with developing countries demanding compensation from the worst polluting countries for damage they say they are already suffering.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Nicholas Kulish

articles.headline: In Fracas on Health Coverage, Some Democrats Feel Exposed
articles.snippet: The fumbled rollout of the health care law has forced candidates, including three congressional incumbents in New Hampshire, to balance their loyalty to the White House with the needs of an angry constituency.
articles.abstract: The fumbled rollout of the health care law has forced candidates, including three congressional incumbents in New Hampshire, to balance their loyalty to the White House with the needs of an angry constituency.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.H. — The awards ceremony on Friday evening for New Hampshire’s police forces was full of pomp (a bagpipe band in full Scottish regalia), circumstance (tales of heroism and tragedy told to standing ovations), officers in dress uniforms and a show of support from the state’s full congressional delegation.

articles.headline: Dispute Over Gay Marriage Erupts in Cheney Family
articles.snippet: Mary Cheney and her wife sharply criticized a comment by Ms. Cheney’s sister, Liz Cheney, a candidate for the Senate in Wyoming.
articles.abstract: Mary Cheney and her wife sharply criticized a comment by Ms. Cheney’s sister, Liz Cheney, a candidate for the Senate in Wyoming.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:09 p.m. | WASHINGTON — They were the towheaded sisters who tagged along on campaigns, polite and smiling, as their father rose through Wyoming and then Washington politics to become one of the most powerful men in the country.

articles.headline: Disney Struggles to Make Its Free Gaming Apps Pay
articles.snippet: Mobile games are a major growth opportunity, and analysts say a recent flop underscores the challenges Disney faces in a shifting marketplace.
articles.abstract: Mobile games are a major growth opportunity, and analysts say a recent flop underscores the challenges Disney faces in a shifting marketplace.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Two months ago, Disney released a sequel to Where’s My Water?, a hit smartphone game about a showering alligator. Hopes were high: Disney had pointed to the original game as evidence of overdue traction in mobile gaming.

articles.headline: Pressure Builds to Finish Volcker Rule on Wall St. Oversight
articles.snippet: The push to reshape financial oversight hinges on negotiations in the coming weeks over the so-called Volcker Rule, a regulation that strikes at the heart of Wall Street risk-taking.
articles.abstract: The push to reshape financial oversight hinges on negotiations in the coming weeks over the so-called Volcker Rule, a regulation that strikes at the heart of Wall Street risk-taking.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration, currently stumbling through the health care overhaul, has reached a critical stage in its other signature effort: reining in Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Developing a Fax Machine to Copy Life on Mars
articles.snippet: DNA sequencing and DNA synthesis are becoming faster and cheaper, and J. Craig Venter wants to use the technology to bring Martian life to Earth.
articles.abstract: DNA sequencing and DNA synthesis are becoming faster and cheaper, and J. Craig Venter wants to use the technology to bring Martian life to Earth.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOJAVE NATIONAL PRESERVE, Calif. — J. Craig Venter, the maverick scientist, is looking for a new world to conquer — Mars. He wants to detect life on Mars and bring it to Earth using a device called a digital biological converter, or biological teleporter.

articles.headline: Lesson Is Seen in Failure of Law on Medicare in 1989
articles.snippet: Older voters rebelled when Medicare benefits were expanded at the cost of higher premiums, and some lawmakers who were involved see parallels today.
articles.abstract: Older voters rebelled when Medicare benefits were expanded at the cost of higher premiums, and some lawmakers who were involved see parallels today.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Angry Americans voice outrage at being asked to pay more for health coverage. Lawmakers and the White House say the public just doesn’t appreciate the benefits of the new health law. Opponents clamor for repeal before the program fully kicks in.

articles.headline: Inland, No Aid for Survivors of Typhoon
articles.snippet: While international relief workers and Philippines Department of Health workers are now scouring neighborhoods up and down the coast, they are nowhere to be seen in the interior.
articles.abstract: While international relief workers and Philippines Department of Health workers are now scouring neighborhoods up and down the coast, they are nowhere to be seen in the interior.
articles.lead_paragraph: JARO, Philippines — Even as a major international aid effort has begun to take hold around the coastal city of Tacloban, the situation grimly differs just a few miles inland, where large numbers of injured or sick people in interior villages shattered by Typhoon Haiyan more than a week ago have received no assistance.
